summary: This video provides a tutorial on how to speed up a Windows 10 computer with step-by-step instructions and visual demonstrations.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a solid yellow background, transitioning to a title card that reads "COMPUTER TUTORIAL How To Speed Up Windows 10 Performance" in bold, colorful letters against a yellow backdrop. The scene then shifts to a Windows 10 desktop screen, showcasing the default blue wallpaper with the Windows logo. Various icons, including "The PC," "Play File," "Google Chrome," "SHAREit," "Microsoft Edge," "OneDrive," and "RAMMAP 3.95," are visible on the left side of the screen. The taskbar at the bottom displays the time as 10:38 and the date as 11/06/2017, along with several application icons. A cursor moves across the screen, and a text overlay appears, stating "01 Power Option" in a speech bubble, indicating the first step in the tutorial. The video maintains a consistent focus on the desktop environment, emphasizing the instructional content related to optimizing Windows 10 performance.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with speech from a single male speaker with a conversational tone, introducing an easy tutorial and announcing that he'll show how to speed up Windows 10 for free without any software. Following that, the speaker says, "Let's begin this tutorial." There is background music with an upbeat mood playing with a steelpan instrument.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop screen, showcasing the default blue wallpaper with the Windows logo. The taskbar at the bottom displays several icons, including Google Chrome, File Explorer, and Microsoft Edge. The Start menu is open, revealing various applications and settings, such as Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, and File Explorer. The date and time are visible in the bottom right corner, showing "10/06/2017" and "10:39 AM." The cursor moves to the search bar, types "power," and selects "Power Options" from the search results. The Power Options window opens, displaying different power plans and settings. The cursor adjusts the screen brightness slider and then closes the Power Options window. The desktop screen returns to its original state, with the Start menu closed and the taskbar icons visible. The video concludes with the desktop screen remaining static, showing the default wallpaper and taskbar icons.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a female speaker explaining the first step to something, using a calm, instructional tone, mentioning "power options". She describes navigating the start menu to find and click on the power options. She notes that the default setting on her computer is "balanced", then instructs the listener to change it to "high performance." The speaker then advises to close the window.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop featuring a blue background with the Windows logo. Several icons are visible on the desktop, including "This PC," "Recycle Bin," "Google Chrome," "Games," "Snip & Sketch," "OneNote," and "Daisy." The taskbar at the bottom shows the time as 10:39 and the date as 13/09/2017. The cursor moves to the right side of the screen, clicks on the Start button, and opens the Start menu. The cursor then selects "View" from the menu, revealing options such as "Toolbars," "Show Task View button," and "Show Windows Ink Workspace button." The cursor hovers over "Toolbars" and opens a submenu with options like "Cortana," "Show Task View button," and "Show Windows Ink Workspace button." The cursor then moves to the search bar at the bottom of the screen and types "Task Manager." The Task Manager window opens, displaying a list of startup applications with their status, publisher, and startup impact. The cursor highlights "Microsoft OneDrive" and right-clicks to reveal options such as "Open file location," "Disable," and "Enable." The cursor selects "Disable," and the status of "Microsoft OneDrive" changes to "Disabled." The video concludes with the Task Manager window still open, showing the updated list of startup applications. Throughout the video, the Windows 10 desktop background remains consistent, and the time and date on the taskbar do not change.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker explaining the next step as being "startup apps". He is speaking in a calm and informative tone. He proceeds to give instructions on how to disable unwanted apps, emphasizing to avoid disabling antivirus or Microsoft apps. His advice is that it will help to speed up the PC. Music plays in the background, with its genre and style being difficult to determine, it has a generally subdued tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop featuring a blue background with a glowing window design. Several icons are visible on the left side of the screen, including 'The PC,' 'Pyrofile,' 'Google Chrome,' 'SHAREit,' 'Superhuman Folders,' and 'OneDrive.' A notification banner at the bottom reads '03 Defragment' with a yellow speech bubble and a pink thumbs-up icon. The Windows Start menu is then opened, displaying various applications such as 'Google Chrome,' 'Microsoft Edge,' 'File Explorer,' 'Skype,' 'Twitter,' 'Minecraft,' and 'OneNote.' The user types 'defrag' into the search bar, leading to a list of search results, with 'Defragment and Optimize Drives' highlighted. The user clicks on this option, opening the 'Optimize Drives' window, which shows the status of drives C: and E: as 'OK (0% Fragmented).' The user clicks the 'Analyze' button, and the status of drive C: changes to '0% Fragmented.' The user then clicks the 'Optimize' button, and the status of drive C: changes to '0% Fragmented.' The video concludes with the 'Optimize Drives' window still open, showing the status of the drives and the scheduled optimization settings.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a single male speaker introducing the "third step" as "defragment". He calmly explains how to access the defragmentation tool by right-clicking the start menu, typing "defragment and optimize drives", and selecting the program. He instructs the listener to choose the C drive where the operating system is installed and click "optimize". He then notes the process may take a few minutes and to close the window when finished.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop featuring a blue background with a light effect resembling a window. The desktop is populated with various icons, including folders and applications such as 'The PC,' 'Pygame,' 'Google Chrome,' 'Steam,' 'SHAREit,' 'Microsoft Edge,' 'OneDrive,' and 'RAMSH 3977 ATS.' The taskbar at the bottom displays the time as 11:39 and the date as 13/08/2017. The cursor moves to the 'This PC' icon, right-clicks, and selects 'Manage,' opening the 'Computer Management' window. The 'Disk Management' section is highlighted, showing the 'Local Disk (C:)' with details about its type, used space, free space, and capacity. The cursor then clicks on the 'Disk Cleanup' option, opening a new window that lists files to be deleted, such as 'Temporary Internet Files,' 'System Restore and Shadow Copies,' and 'Windows Update Cleanup.' The user proceeds to select all files and clicks 'OK,' initiating the cleanup process. The 'Disk Cleanup' window shows the progress of the cleanup, indicating that the process is ongoing. The video concludes with the 'Disk Cleanup' window still open, showing the progress of the cleanup process, while the 'Computer Management' window remains visible in the background.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker describing the first step as "disk cleanup." He explains to right-click on the "C menu, C drive," and select "properties," then to click on "disk cleanup." Reassuring, he says not to worry as it will only clean temporary and unwanted files. A new window appears and he then instructs to click on "clean up system files." As the system calculates, the speaker instructs to click on "Okay," which is then followed by the phrase "delete files." This is followed by an affirmation, "Okay."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop featuring a blue background with a light window design. Several icons are visible on the desktop, including "The PC," "File Explorer," "Google Chrome," "SHAREit," "Snip & Sketch," "Microsoft Forms," and "Daisy." The taskbar at the bottom shows the time as 1:31 PM and the date as 10/06/2017. A text overlay in the bottom left corner reads "05 Visual Settings" with a yellow circle and a blue speech bubble. The user then opens the Start menu by clicking the Windows icon, revealing options such as "System Information," "System Configuration," "Clean Sys Vol Folder," and "Settings." The user types "sy" into the search bar, and the search results update to show "System Information," "System Configuration," "Settings," "System," "Check for updates," "Windows Update," "Reset this PC," "About your PC," "Taskbar notification area," and "System." The user selects "System" from the search results, opening the "System" window, which displays information about the computer, including the processor, RAM, and display. The user then opens the "System Properties" window, showing details such as the computer name, processor, and memory. The user navigates to the "Advanced" tab and clicks on "Settings" under "Performance," opening the "Performance Options" window. The user selects "Adjust for best performance" and clicks "Apply" and "OK" to save the changes. The video concludes with the "Performance Options" window still open, showing the selected settings.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a man speaking in an informative tone, describing a sequence of steps. He mentions, "Fifth step, visual settings," and proceeds to explain actions like clicking the start menu and searching for the system, then adjusting for best performance. Light, ambient music plays softly in the background. The man continues with instructions to enable certain features and select them. He then says, "Show shadows under mouse pointer, that's enough for me."

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a static view of a Windows 10 desktop screen, featuring a blue background with a light window design. On the left side of the screen, there are several icons, including "The PC," "File Re," "Google Chrome," "GAMES," "Microsoft Forms," and "OneDrive." The taskbar at the bottom displays the Windows Start button, search bar, and several pinned applications such as File Explorer, Microsoft Edge, and Google Chrome. The system tray on the right side shows the time as 11:43 AM and the date as 15/08/2017. The desktop remains unchanged throughout the video, with no visible actions or movements.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip contains speech. There is a suggestion for the listeners to stay tuned. It is spoken by a male individual in a friendly tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop featuring a blue background with a glowing window design. Several icons are visible, including 'The PC,' 'File Explorer,' 'Google Chrome,' 'Games,' 'Networkshare Folders,' and 'OneDrive.' The taskbar shows the time as 13:14 and the date as 11/06/2017. The cursor moves to the 'File Explorer' icon, opens it, and navigates to the 'Run' command in the search bar, typing '%temp%' to open the temporary files folder. The cursor then selects all files in the 'Temp' folder and attempts to delete them, but a pop-up message indicates that the folder cannot be deleted because it is in use by another program. The video concludes with the cursor still on the 'Try Again' button in the pop-up message.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker explaining, "The next important step is temporary files delete". He then explains how to do that, "start and type run" and open the run command, instructing the listener to type the percentage symbol, the letters "TEMP", and then a percentage symbol again. He then instructs the listener to press control plus A to select all the items, then right click to delete. There is a short period of silence at the end of the clip.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop featuring a blue background with a glowing window design. Several icons are visible on the desktop, including "The PC," "File Reo," "Google Chrome," "SHARE," "Merchandise Folders," and "Dass." The taskbar at the bottom shows the time as 11:32 and the date as 10/06/2017. The cursor moves to the search bar, types "run," and opens the Run dialog box. The user types "temp" into the Run dialog box and presses Enter, opening the Temp folder. The Temp folder contains various files and folders, with the cursor highlighting the "Temp" folder. The user then deletes the contents of the Temp folder, leaving it empty. The scene transitions to the user opening the Run dialog box again, this time typing "prefetch" and pressing Enter, opening the Prefetch folder. The Prefetch folder contains numerous files, and the user selects all files using the "Ctrl+A" shortcut. The video concludes with the user right-clicking on the selected files, opening a context menu with options such as "Add to 'Temp' and email," "Compress to 'Temp.zip' and email," "Copy," "Create shortcut," "Delete," and "Properties." The cursor hovers over the "Delete" option, indicating the user's intention to delete the selected files.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker guiding someone through computer tasks. He directs the listener to "click on the start menu," "type run," and "select the run result" in a clear, instructional tone. The speaker continues with further steps, including typing "TEMP", pressing okay, and continuing with "control plus A" to delete items. The same speaker then introduces another round of tasks, directing to start, run, and then type "prefetch." The clip concludes with instructions to press okay and then control plus A to select all items and delete them.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a Windows desktop featuring a blue background with a Windows logo. The desktop is populated with several icons, including 'This PC,' 'File Explorer,' 'Google Chrome,' and 'SHAREit.' The taskbar at the bottom displays the time as 11:38 and the date as 10/20/2017. The cursor moves to the 'File Explorer' icon, opening a window that reveals folders such as 'Quick access,' 'Desktop,' 'Downloads,' and 'Documents.' The cursor then navigates to the 'Run' option in the Start menu, opening a dialog box where 'msconfig' is typed into the 'Open' field. The 'OK' button is clicked, leading to the 'System Configuration' window, which displays a list of services. The cursor selects 'Hide all Microsoft services,' and a 'SUBSCRIBE FOR MORE VIDEOS' banner appears in red at the top right corner of the screen. The video concludes with the 'System Configuration' window still open, showing the updated list of services with Microsoft services hidden.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker providing instructions, stating "the next important step, you have to watch hide Windows services." He continues, guiding the listener to "click on start" and type "run" to execute a command, specifying the command as "msconfig." The speaker instructs to navigate to the "services menu" and emphasize the importance of clicking "hide all Microsoft services," warning not to disable anything. His tone is instructional and clear.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop featuring a blue background with a glowing window design. Several icons are visible on the left side, including "The PC," "Play Reo," "Google Chrome," "SHAREit," "RemoShore Folders," and "DOS." A text overlay at the bottom reads "08 Regedit," accompanied by a yellow circle and a pink arrow pointing to the right. The Windows TV logo is displayed in the top right corner. The scene transitions to the Windows Start menu, showcasing various applications such as Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Skype, Twitter, and OneNote. The user then opens the search bar and types "regedit," leading to the Run dialog box where "regedit" is typed into the search field. The user clicks "OK," and the Regedit application opens, displaying the Windows Registry Editor interface. The video concludes with the Regedit window open, showing the Windows Registry Editor interface with a list of registry keys and values.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a female speaker stating, "the last step is Regedit". She then instructs the listener, "to do that type run on the search" and continues, "and open the run command."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop featuring a blue background with a light effect resembling a window. The desktop is adorned with several icons, including 'This PC,' 'Recycle Bin,' 'Google Chrome,' and 'SHAREit.' The taskbar at the bottom displays the Start button, search bar, and pinned applications such as File Explorer, Microsoft Edge, and Google Chrome. The system tray shows the time as 11:37 and the date as 15/06/2017. The user opens the 'Run' dialog box, types 'regedit,' and presses Enter, launching the Registry Editor. The Registry Editor window appears, displaying a hierarchical list of registry keys on the left and a detailed view of the selected key on the right. The user navigates through the registry, expanding the 'Computer' key to reveal subkeys like 'HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT,' 'HKEY_CURRENT_USER,' and 'HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE.' The user then selects 'HKEY_CURRENT_USER' and further navigates to 'Control Panel\Mouse,' where various mouse settings are listed. The user opens the 'Mouse' settings, revealing options such as 'DoubleClickSpeed,' 'MouseSensitivity,' and 'MouseThreshold1.' The user adjusts the 'MouseSensitivity' value to 10 and saves the changes. The video concludes with the user navigating back to the 'Control Panel' and selecting 'Display,' where display settings are listed, including 'Screen Resolution' and 'Display Adapter Properties.' The user opens the 'Display' settings, revealing options such as 'Screen Resolution,' 'Display Adapter Properties,' and 'Wallpaper.' The video ends with the user navigating back to the 'Control Panel' and selecting 'Display,' where display settings are listed, including 'Screen Resolution' and 'Display Adapter Properties.' The user opens the 'Display' settings, revealing options such as 'Screen Resolution,' 'Display Adapter Properties,' and 'Wallpaper.' The video ends with the user navigating back to the 'Control Panel' and selecting 'Display,' where display settings are listed, including 'Screen Resolution' and 'Display Adapter Properties.' The user opens the 'Display' settings, revealing options such as 'Screen Resolution,' 'Display Adapter Properties,' and 'Wallpaper.' The video ends with the user navigating back to the 'Control Panel' and selecting 'Display,' where display settings are listed, including 'Screen Resolution' and 'Display Adapter Properties.' The user opens the 'Display' settings, revealing options
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker providing instructions. He uses a calm, instructional tone, stating "Here you have to type Regedit," and continues to guide the listener through steps. A brief pause is followed by further instructions about selecting "H-key current user" and clicking on control panel. Subsequently, the male speaker directs the user to click on the mouse and change the value data to 10 to enable "faster reactions".  He then moves on to desktop, asking the user to go to "Menu show delay" and change the value to ten again. The audio concludes with him stating "then press okay".

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a Windows 10 desktop screen, featuring a blue background with the Windows logo. Several icons are visible on the left side of the screen, including "The PC," "File Re," "Google Chrome," "SHARE," "NVIDIA GeForce," "Oasis," and "RAMSHY 3977 ATS." The taskbar at the bottom shows the time as 11:38 and the date as 13/08/2017. A right-click context menu is open, displaying options such as "Graphics Properties," "View," "Sort by," "Paste shortcut," "Paste," "Graphics Properties," "Graphics Options," "New," "Display settings," and "Refresh." The mouse cursor is positioned over the "Graphics Properties" option. The scene then transitions to a green background with a white rectangle in the center, containing the text "Easy Classes" at the top, followed by "Thank You" in large letters, "Like & Share" in blue, and "SUBSCRIBE" in red with a green outline. Below this, the text "FOR MORE VIDEOS" is displayed in black. The video concludes with this message, encouraging viewers to like, share, and subscribe for more content.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a melodic instrumental piece that sounds meditative and soothing. A male voice then speaks, expressing hope that a video will be helpful to the listener and their friends. He asks the audience to like and share the video, and reminds them to subscribe to the channel to watch future content, signing off with a "thank you guys."
